chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Suspected cow's milk allergy
chapter.summary: Covers the management of children with suspected IgE- and non-IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth to 5 years.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.fullItemName: Scenario: Confirmed non-IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage suspected IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If a diagnosis of immunoglobulin (Ig)E-mediated cow's milk allergy is suspected following initial assessment:

  • Arrange immediate ambulance transfer to Accident and Emergency if:
    • There are systemic symptoms or suspected anaphylaxis with or without angio-oedema. See the CKS topic on Angio-oedema and anaphylaxis for more information on emergency management.
  • Arrange referral to a specialist allergy clinic for allergy testing to confirm the diagnosis and guide management, the urgency depending on clinical judgement, if:
    • There is a history of one or more severe systemic reactions. See the CKS topic on Angio-oedema and anaphylaxis for more information.
    • There is a history of concurrent asthma; or a severe reaction to a trace amount of food allergen (airborne, or contact through skin only). See the CKS topic on Asthma for more information.
    • There is significant atopic eczema, where multiple or cross-reactive food allergies are suspected. See the CKS topic on Eczema - atopic for more information.
    • The diagnosis is uncertain.
    • There are multiple suspected food allergies.
    • Allergy testing to confirm the diagnosis is not available in primary care.
    • Allergy testing is needed to assess whether tolerance has developed, depending on local referral pathways and availability.
    • There is persistent parental or carer suspicion of food allergy (particularly if there are difficult or perplexing symptoms) despite a lack of supporting history, or persistent anxiety about the diagnosis of food allergy.
  • Whilst awaiting specialist assessment, consider arranging referral to a paediatric dietitian.
    • The GP Infant Feeding Network (gpifn.org.uk) hosts the Milk Allergy in Primary Care (MAP) Guideline 2019 which has useful algorithms on suspected and confirmed cow's milk allergy.
    • If the child is symptomatic while exclusively breastfed (rare), actively support continued breastfeeding. Advise the mother to exclude all cow's milk protein from her diet, and advise on the need for dietary supplementation with calcium and vitamin D according to local protocols.
    • Note: if the infant is asymptomatic on exclusive breastfeeding, do not exclude cow's milk from the maternal diet.
    • If the infant is formula-fed or mixed feeding and the mother is unable to return to exclusive breastfeeding, advise a trial of extensively hydrolysed formula (eHF).
  • Advise parents/carers on sources of information and support:
    • The national charity Allergy UK (www.allergyuk.org).
      • This provides support, advice, and information for people living with allergy. It provides a factsheet on Cow's milk allergy, a leaflet Could it be cow's milk allergy?, and a range of Allergy Recipes free from common allergens including cow's milk.
    • The charity CMPA Support (www.cowsmilkproteinallergysupport.webs.com).
      • This aims to raise awareness of cow's milk allergy; provides information, support, and practical advice to parents/carers; and maintains a list of 'free-from' foods that can be bought.
    • The patient information leaflet Cow's milk protein allergy available on the www.patient.info.
    • The NHS information leaflet What should I do if I think my baby is allergic or intolerant to cows' milk?.
    • Advise how to check and interpret food labels and recognise food allergens in ingredients lists of food products.
      • This includes lists of alternative terms for specific food allergens (milk proteins may be labelled as containing sodium caeinate, calcium caeinate, potassium caeinate, magnesium caeinate, protein hydrolysate, casein, milk serum, lactoalbumin, or lactoglobulin, for example), and advice on precautionary allergen labelling, such as 'may contain' or 'not suitable for' statements.
      • Advise that loose foods (for example bought from markets or open bakeries) and foods imported from outside the EU, may not have food ingredient labelling, and may be best avoided.
      • 'Free from' product finder apps, such as foodmaestro.me/food-app/ or www.spoon.guru/the-app/ may be helpful. 
  • If a diagnosis of IgE-mediated allergy is confirmed, follow-up is usually arranged by the specialist allergy service.
    • Follow-up may include serial allergy testing and subsequent oral food challenge to test for acquired tolerance.
    • Parents/carers should be given written advice on prompt recognition and management of acute symptoms following accidental or new exposures, for example using a British Society for Allergy and Clinical Immunology (BSACI) Allergy Action Plan.
    • Advise parents/carers to have oral antihistamines available at home, in case there is a return of symptoms on reintroduction or any accidental exposure. See the section on Antihistamines in Prescribing information for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Allergy testing
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Allergy testing may involve initial skin prick testing or measuring serum-specific immunoglobulin (Ig)E levels to cow's milk, and should be undertaken by healthcare professionals with the appropriate facilities, expertise, and training to select and perform tests, and interpret results. Testing may be performed in primary care if the expertise to conduct and interpret the tests is available.

  • Skin prick testing involves the epicutaneous introduction of allergen extracts with a lancet, typically to the volar aspect of the forearm. The site is inspected after 15 minutes and compared with positive and negative controls (observer dependent), to detect sensitization to allergens.
  • Serum-specific IgE testing is widely available, but results are not immediate and may take days to weeks to process.
  • Both allergy tests are sensitive but not specific, and have various limitations and potential difficulties in interpretation:
    • Skin prick test sensitization may be suppressed by recent antihistamine, beta-blocker, tricyclic antidepressant (TCA), and topical corticosteroid use.
      • Serum-specific IgE testing may be more appropriate when skin prick testing is not possible, or when skin prick testing taken with the clinical history give equivocal results.
    • Allergy testing cannot distinguish between sensitization (presence of IgE antibodies) and clinical allergy, so test results must be interpreted in the context of the clinical history.
      • Some people have positive test results but do not develop symptoms of clinical allergy on exposure to the relevant food allergen (food sensitization only and a false positive result).
      • Some people may have a strong clinical history of IgE-mediated food allergy but negative allergy test results (false negative result).
    • A large reaction on skin prick testing or high concentrations of serum-specific IgE are associated with an increased likelihood of cow's milk allergy, but they do not predict symptom severity.
  • Allergy testing may also be used to assess whether tolerance has developed in a person with a confirmed food allergy. Re-testing may be arranged every 12–18 months depending on local pathways and protocols.
  • If the results of allergy testing do not correspond with the clinical history, or the history is equivocal, an oral food challenge in a supervised setting may be needed to confirm the diagnosis:
    • Oral food challenge is the gold standard for diagnosis of food allergy, and is an accurate and sensitive test. It involves the administration of increasing quantities of baked or fresh cow's milk under medical supervision, starting with direct mucosal exposure (allergen contact with the lips) and then titrated oral ingestion as tolerated. The rate of dose escalation, the time interval between doses, and observation period after the challenge depends on the individual child's presentation. If symptoms are not provoked, the test is negative and clinical allergy can be excluded.

[Fiocchi et al, 2010; RCPCH, 2011; Burks, 2012; Ludman et al, 2013; Venter et al, 2013; Luyt et al, 2014; Muraro, 2014; Steele, 2014; Turnbull, 2015; Venter, 2017; NICE, 2018; Fox, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of suspected IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy are largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Food allergy in under 19s: assessment and diagnosis [NICE, 2018], the British Society for Allergy and Clinical Immunology (BSACI) publication BSACI guideline for the diagnosis and management of cow's milk allergy [Luyt et al, 2014], the European Academy of Allergy and Clinical Immunology (EAACI) publication Food allergy and anaphylaxis guidelines [Muraro, 2014], the European Society for Paediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition (ESPGHAN) guidelines Diagnostic approach and management of cow’s-milk protein allergy in infants and children [Koletzko et al, 2012], the Resuscitation Council (UK) guideline Emergency treatment of anaphylactic reactions: guidelines for healthcare providers [Resuscitation Council (UK), 2012], expert opinion in a review article on cow's milk allergy [Ludman et al, 2013], on non-IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy [Venter, 2017], and expert opinion in the updated Milk allergy in primary care (MAP) guideline [Fox, 2019].

Arranging emergency management of suspected anaphylaxis
  • The recommendation to arrange emergency transfer to hospital if there is a suspected systemic reaction or anaphylaxis is based on the Resuscitation Council (UK) guidelines [Resuscitation Council (UK), 2012].
Arranging referral to a specialist allergy clinic
  • The recommendations on referral criteria for suspected IgE-mediated allergy are based on a review of low-quality studies in the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014], the EAACI guidelines [Muraro, 2014], the ESPGHAN guidelines [Koletzko et al, 2012], and expert opinion in a review article [Ludman et al, 2013].
    • The recommendation to refer one or more severe systemic reactions is based on the NICE clinical guideline.
    • The recommendation to refer if there is a history of concurrent asthma is extrapolated from the NICE clinical guideline which recommends this approach when there is a confirmed diagnosis of IgE-mediated allergy, as these children have a higher risk of anaphylaxis. This approach is supported by expert opinion in a review article [Ludman et al, 2013].
    • The recommendation to refer a less severe reaction with only trace exposure is based on the BSACI guideline. This is supported by expert opinion in a review article [Ludman et al, 2013].
    • The recommendation to refer if there is significant atopic eczema is based on the NICE clinical guideline.
    • The recommendation to refer if the diagnosis is uncertain is pragmatic, is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
    • The recommendation to refer if there are multiple suspected food allergies is based on the NICE clinical guideline.
    • The recommendation to refer if allergy testing is not available in primary care is extrapolated from the NICE clinical guideline, which states that diagnostic tests for suspected IgE-mediated cow's milk protein allergy 'should only be undertaken by healthcare professionals with the appropriate competencies to select, perform and interpret them' and should be 'undertaken where there are facilities to deal with an anaphylactic reaction'. It is also pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
    • The recommendation to refer if there is persistent parental or carer suspicion of food allergy is based on the NICE clinical guideline.
Arranging referral to a paediatric dietitian
  • The recommendations to arrange a paediatric dietitian referral are based on expert opinion in the updated iMAP guideline [Fox, 2019], and supported by expert opinion in review articles [Ludman et al, 2013; Venter, 2017].
    • The recommendation to advise trial exclusion of all cow's milk protein from the maternal diet if exclusively breastfeeding is based on the iMAP guideline.
    • The recommendation that if the infant is asymptomatic on exclusive breastfeeding, do not exclude cow's milk from the maternal diet is based on the iMAP guideline.
    • The recommendation to advise a trial of extensively hydrolysed formula if the infant is formula-fed or mixed feeding is based on the iMAP guideline.
Advising on sources of information and support
  • The recommendation to offer information and support is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014], and expert opinion in a review article [Ludman et al, 2013].
    • The BSACI guideline highlights the need to avoid cow's milk and milk products, and advise on dietary substitution with nutritionally suitable milk alternatives. It also notes that nutritionally incomplete substitutes can cause faltering growth and nutritional deficiencies.
    • Expert opinion in a review article notes the importance of education about food labelling, and that management of IgE-mediated reactions may require the use of antihistamines at home [Ludman et al, 2013].
Specialist follow-up of confirmed cases
  • The information that specialist follow-up may include serial allergy testing and subsequent oral food challenge to test for acquired tolerance is based on the iMAP guideline [Fox, 2019].
  • The information to consider the use of an Allergy Action Plan is based on the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014] and is supported by expert opinion in a review article [Ludman et al, 2013].
  • The recommendation for parents/carers to have oral antihistamines at home in case there is a recurrence of symptoms is based on the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage suspected non-IgE-mediated allergy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If a diagnosis of non-immunoglobulin (Ig)E-mediated cow's milk allergy is suspected following initial assessment:

  • Consider referral to a specialist allergy clinic, the urgency depending on clinical judgement, if:
    • There is a history of faltering growth in combination with one or more gastrointestinal symptoms. See the CKS topic on Faltering growth for more information.
    • There is a history of one or more severe delayed reactions. Note: arrange an urgent referral to a paediatric dietitian whilst awaiting specialist assessment if there is suspected severe non-IgE-mediated allergy.
    • The diagnosis is uncertain.
    • There is a history of less severe reaction to a trace amount of food allergen (airborne, or contact through skin only).
    • There are multiple suspected food allergies.
    • There is a history of persistent or poorly controlled asthma. See the CKS topic on Asthma for more information.
    • There is significant atopic eczema, where multiple or cross-reactive food allergies are suspected. See the CKS topic on Eczema - atopic for more information.
    • There is persistent parental or carer suspicion of food allergy (particularly if there are difficult or perplexing symptoms) despite a lack of supporting history, or persistent anxiety about the diagnosis of food allergy.
    • Parents/carers are unable to perform a home reintroduction of cow's milk.
  • Consider arranging referral to a paediatric dietitian, the urgency depending on clinical judgement, who can provide:
    • Regular monitoring of growth and nutritional status (including faltering growth or excessive weight gain).
    • Advice on a cow's milk-free diet including hypoallergenic infant formulas and suitable substitute foods if complementary feeding (weaning).
    • Advice on performing a cow's milk elimination trial and home reintroduction, and follow-up.
    • Advice on inappropriate dietary restriction; vitamin and calcium supplementation; and any feeding problems.
    • Advice if the child is already on a restricted diet for other reasons, which may be cultural or religious.
  • If referral to a specialist allergy clinic is not needed, advise a trial elimination of all cow's milk from the mother's/infant's diet for 2–4 weeks.
    • The GP Infant Feeding Network (gpifn.org.uk) hosts the Milk Allergy in Primary Care (MAP) Guideline 2019 which has useful algorithms on suspected and confirmed cow's milk allergy.
      • Note: it is important to explain and agree on the need for planned early reintroduction of cow's milk when the trial elimination is started.
    • In exclusively breastfed babies, actively support continued breastfeeding where possible. Advise the mother to exclude all cow's milk protein from her diet, and advise on the need for dietary supplementation with calcium and vitamin D according to local protocols.
    • In formula-fed or mixed-fed infants, actively support continued breastfeeding where possible. If the mother is unable to return to exclusive breastfeeding, advise the parents or carers to replace cow's milk-based formula with a hypoallergenic infant formula.
      • If an infant is asymptomatic on exclusive breastfeeding and symptoms only occur with cow's milk-based 'top-up' feeds, advise the mother to continue breastfeeding and to continue to consume cow's milk in her diet. No further action may be needed while the infant remains asymptomatic on exclusive breastfeeding. If 'top-up' feeds are needed, advise the parents or carers to replace cow's milk-based formula with a hypoallergenic infant formula.
      • Note: if there is suspected severe non-IgE-mediated allergy, advise that an amino acid formula (AAF) should be used.
      • Note: if there is suspected severe non-IgE-mediated allergy and/or severe concomitant atopic eczema, consider seeking specialist advice on the need to avoid other foods such as soya protein and egg from the diet as well.
    • In infants who are complementary feeding (weaning) and older children, advise the parents or carers to exclude cow's milk protein from the child's diet and ensure referral to a paediatric dietitian has been arranged, for ongoing nutritional guidance and follow-up.
  • Following strict adherence to a trial elimination of all cow's milk for 2–4 weeks:
    • If there is a clear improvement in symptoms, arrange a home reintroduction of cow's milk into the mother's or infant's diet to confirm the diagnosis of non-IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy.
      • Note: in exclusively breastfed babies, cow's milk should be reintroduced into the maternal diet in previously consumed amounts, over a one-week period.
      • If there is no return of symptoms, a diagnosis of cow's milk allergy is not confirmed and the mother/infant may resume normal feeding.
      • If there is a return of symptoms, the mother/infant should continue to exclude all cow's milk from the diet. If formula-fed or mixed feeding, a hypoallergenic infant formula should be advised. If symptoms clearly improve, a diagnosis of cow's milk allergy is confirmed. See the Scenario on Confirmed non-IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy for more information on ongoing management.
    • If there is no clear improvement in symptoms:
      • If cow's milk allergy is still suspected, arrange referral to a specialist allergy clinic and consider seeking specialist advice on the need to avoid other foods such as soya protein and egg from the diet as well. If formula-fed or mixed feeding and a trial of extensively hydrolysed formula (eHF) has already been done, consider starting a trial of amino acid formula (AAF) whilst awaiting specialist assessment.
      • If cow's milk allergy is no longer suspected, the mother/infant may resume normal feeding and consider referral to a local paediatric service for further assessment if symptoms persist.
    • The iMAP Milk Allergy Guideline Home reintroduction protocol leaflet may be helpful for parents/carers.
  • Advise parents/carers on sources of information and support:
    • Advise that allergy testing with skin prick tests or serum-specific IgE antibody tests are not needed to confirm the diagnosis of non-IgE-mediated allergy.
    • The national charity Allergy UK (www.allergyuk.org).
      • This provides support, advice, and information for people living with allergy. It provides a factsheet on Cow's milk allergy, a leaflet Could it be cow's milk allergy?, and a range of Allergy Recipes free from common allergens including cow's milk.
    • The charity CMPA Support (www.cowsmilkproteinallergysupport.webs.com).
      • This aims to raise awareness of cow's milk allergy; provides information, support and practical advice to parents/carers; and maintains a list of 'free-from' foods that can be bought.
    • The iMAP Milk Allergy Guideline Initial factsheet for parents and Initial factsheet for infants being exclusively or partly breastfed.
    • The patient information leaflet Cow's milk protein allergy available on the www.patient.info.
    • The NHS information leaflet What should I do if I think my baby is allergic or intolerant to cows' milk?.
    • Advise how to check and interpret food labels and recognise food allergens in ingredients lists of food products.
      • This includes lists of alternative terms for specific food allergens (milk proteins may be labelled as containing sodium caeinate, calcium caeinate, potassium caeinate, magnesium caeinate, protein hydrolysate, casein, milk serum, lactoalbumin, or lactoglobulin, for example), and advice on precautionary allergen labelling, such as 'may contain' or 'not suitable for' statements.
      • Advise that loose and unwrapped foods (for example bought from markets or open bakeries) and foods imported from outside the EU, may not have food ingredient labelling, and may be best avoided. Loose or unwrapped foods may include ham containing casein; pastry may be glazed with cow's milk; and biscuits may contain margarine containing whey.
      • 'Free from' product finder apps, such as foodmaestro.me/food-app/ or www.spoon.guru/the-app/ may be helpful.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Hypoallergenic infant formulas
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The choice of cow's milk substitute should take into account the child's age, growth, severity of symptoms, and nutritional composition needed. A paediatric dietitian may advise on the appropriate infant milk formula to prescribe.

  • Extensively hydrolysed formulas (eHFs) are usually used first-line.
    • They are whey or casein-based and are generally well tolerated by infants and children with cow's milk allergy.
  • Amino acid formulas (AAFs) should be reserved for children:
    • With severe symptoms of IgE- or non-IgE-mediated allergy or a history of anaphylaxis.
    • Who cannot tolerate or have ongoing symptoms with eHFs.
    • Whose symptoms do not respond to maternal avoidance of cow's milk, or have symptoms while exclusively breastfeeding.
  • Partially hydrolysed formulas are not recommended in the management of cow's milk allergy.
  • Soya protein-based formulas should not be used first-line.
    • They may be used in some children over 6 months of age who do not have soya allergy.
    • They should not be used in infants less than six months of age or in those with suspected soya allergy.
      • The absorption of minerals and trace elements may be lower because of their phytate content.
      • They contain appreciable amounts of isoflavones with a weak oestrogenic action that can lead to high serum concentrations in infants, with a theorized hormonal effect on the reproductive system, however there is no consensus in the literature.
      • Be aware that up to 60% of people with non-IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy and up to 14% with IgE-mediated allergy also react to soya.
  • Other milk substitutes
    • Alternative 'milk' beverages such as almond, oat, coconut, or rice milks have poor nutritional value compared with cow's milk, and are not suitable for use as an infant's main drink under one year of age.
      • Rice milk is not advised before the age of 4.5 years due to its natural inorganic arsenic content.
    • Lactose-free formulas contain intact cow's milk protein, and should not be used in suspected or confirmed cow's milk allergy.
    • Other mammalian milk proteins (including unmodified cow, sheep, buffalo, horse, or goat's milk) are not recommended for infants with cow's milk allergy.
      • They are not adequately nutritious to provide the sole food source for infants.
      • There is a risk of possible allergenic cross-reactivity with milk or formulas based on other mammalian milk proteins.
  • The Milk Allergy in Primary Care (MAP) guideline advises when prescribing hypoallergenic infant formula, until complementary feeding (weaning), a fully formula-fed infant will normally need around 2–3 tins of formula per week. It has a different taste and smell to cow's milk-based formula, and can be gradually introduced into a child's feeds over several days before replacing cow's milk-based formula completely.
  • The First Steps Nutrition Trust (firststepsnutrition.org) is an independent public health nutrition charity that provides information on the range and composition of infant milks and breastmilk substitutes.
    • Its publication Specialised infant milks in the UK: infants 0–6 months. Information for health professionals contains detailed information on extensively hydrolysed formulas (eHFs), amino acid formulas (AAFs), and soya protein-based infant formulas which are available in the UK.
  • The British Dietetic Association (www.bda.uk.com) has a Food Fact Sheet Suitable milks for children with cows milk allergy which may also be helpful.

[Fiocchi et al, 2010; Ludman et al, 2013; Venter et al, 2013; Luyt et al, 2014; Muraro, 2014; Venter, 2017; Fox, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on managing suspected non-IgE-mediated allergy are largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Food allergy in under 19s: assessment and diagnosis [NICE, 2018], the British Society for Allergy and Clinical Immunology (BSACI) publication BSACI guideline for the diagnosis and management of cow's milk allergy [Luyt et al, 2014], the European Academy of Allergy and Clinical Immunology (EAACI) publications Food allergy and anaphylaxis guidelines [Muraro, 2014] and Diagnosis and management of non‐IgE gastrointestinal allergies in breastfed infants - an EAACI Position Paper [Meyer, 2019]; the European Society for Paediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition (ESPGHAN) guidelines Diagnostic approach and management of cow’s-milk protein allergy in infants and children [Koletzko et al, 2012], the World Allergy Organization publication Diagnosis and rationale for action against cow's milk allergy (DRACMA): a summary report [Fiocchi et al, 2010], expert opinion in review articles on cow's milk allergy [Ludman et al, 2013], on non-IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy [Venter et al, 2013; Venter, 2017], in the updated Milk allergy in primary care (MAP) guideline [Fox, 2019], and extrapolated from expert opinion in a review article on IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy [Martorell-Aragones, 2015].

Arranging referral to a specialist allergy clinic
  • The recommendations on referral criteria for suspected non-IgE-mediated allergy are based on a review of low-quality studies in the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014], the EAACI guidelines [Muraro, 2014], the ESPGHAN guidelines [Koletzko et al, 2012], and expert opinion in a review article [Ludman et al, 2013].
    • The recommendation to refer if there is faltering growth with gastrointestinal symptoms is based on the NICE clinical guideline, as this usually indicates severe allergy. The recommendation to refer a severe delayed reaction is based on the NICE clinical guideline. The updated MAP guideline notes that such cases of suspected severe allergy should be referred urgently, and advocates urgent referral to a paediatric dietitian whilst awaiting specialist assessment.
    • The recommendation to refer if the diagnosis is uncertain is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
    • The recommendation to refer a less severe reaction with only trace exposure is based on the BSACI guideline, as these children are not suitable for a home reintroduction of cow's milk. This is supported by expert opinion in a review article [Ludman et al, 2013].
    • The recommendation to refer if there are multiple suspected food allergies is based on the NICE clinical guideline and is supported by the BSACI guideline.
    • The recommendation to refer if there is a history of persistent or poorly controlled asthma is extrapolated from the NICE clinical guideline which recommends this approach when there is a confirmed diagnosis of IgE-mediated allergy. This approach is supported by the BSACI guideline and expert opinion in a review article [Ludman et al, 2013].
    • The recommendation to refer if there is significant atopic eczema is based on the NICE clinical guideline.
    • The recommendation to refer if there is persistent parental or carer suspicion of food allergy is based on the NICE clinical guideline.
    • The recommendation to refer if parents/carers are unable to perform a home reintroduction is based on the BSACI guideline.
Arranging referral to a paediatric dietitian
  • The recommendations to arrange a paediatric dietitian referral are based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014], the EAACI guidelines [Muraro, 2014], expert opinion in the updated iMAP guideline [Fox, 2019], and expert opinion in review articles [Ludman et al, 2013; Venter, 2017].
    • The recommendation on monitoring growth and nutritional status is based on the NICE guideline, the BSACI guideline, and expert opinion in a review article [Ludman et al, 2013].
      • The BSACI guideline advises that a dietitian assesses all children on a milk-free diet for calcium intake and gives advice on calcium-rich foods if needed, as well as regularly monitoring weight and growth. It notes that failure to involve a dietitian may lead to inappropriate feeding, prolonged unnecessary food exclusion, and nutritional deficiencies.
      • Malnutrition may occur in children on exclusion diets and children with newly diagnosed food allergies, as well as obesity [Ludman et al, 2013].
    • The recommendation on advising about suitable milk substitutes and substitute foods if complementary feeding (weaning), vitamin and calcium supplementation, and any feeding problems is based on expert opinion in a review article [Venter, 2017].
    • The recommendation on monitoring during an elimination trial and home reintroduction of cow's milk is based on the NICE clinical guideline, the BSACI guideline, the EAACI position paper on breastfed infants [Meyer, 2019], and the World Allergy Organization publication [Fiocchi et al, 2010].
      • The NICE guideline notes that an elimination diet can be initiated in primary care, however, a dietitian should be involved to reduce the time to diagnosis, offer advice on nutritional issues, follow up, and advise on appropriate milk substitutes for formula-fed infants.
      • A diagnostic elimination diet should ideally be implemented with the support of a dietitian or nutritionist or suitably qualified healthcare professional, as this may prevent any negative nutritional impact [Meyer, 2019].
    • The recommendation on advising about restricted diets is extrapolated from the NICE guideline.
Advising on a trial elimination diet
  • The recommendations on advising on a trial elimination of cow's milk from the diet are based on the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014], the EAACI position paper on breastfed infants [Meyer, 2019], the ESPGHAN guidelines [Koletzko et al, 2012], expert opinion in the updated iMAP guideline [Fox, 2019], and expert opinion in review articles [Ludman et al, 2013; Venter, 2017].
    • The recommendation to explain and agree on the need for planned early reintroduction of cow's milk when the trial elimination is started is based on expert opinion in a review article [Venter, 2017]. The iMAP guideline update notes that there is a risk of over-diagnosis of cow's milk allergy if milk exclusion diets are not followed up by diagnostic milk reintroduction to see if symptoms return.
    • The recommendations on the duration of the elimination trial are based on the iMAP guideline. These are supported by the BSACI guideline, the EAACI position paper, and expert opinion in a review article which notes that most symptoms will usually resolve within two to four weeks of a cow's milk elimination diet [Ludman et al, 2013]. The EAACI position paper notes the aim of the elimination trial is to show symptom improvement or resolution on elimination, followed by a worsening or return of symptoms when cow's milk is reintroduced.
    • The recommendation to actively support continued breastfeeding where possible in exclusively breastfed infants is based on the MAP guideline.
    • The recommendations on maternal exclusion of all dietary cow's milk protein and assessing the need for calcium and vitamin D supplementation to reduce the risk of nutritional deficiencies are based on the MAP guideline, the BSACI guideline, and expert opinion in a review article [Ludman et al, 2013]. They are also pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
    • The information on replacing cow's milk-based 'top-up' feeds if needed is based on the MAP guideline.
    • The recommendation to consider seeking specialist advice on the need to avoid other food allergens if there is suspected severe non-IgE-mediated allergy and/or severe concomitant atopic eczema is based on the MAP guideline.
    • The recommendation on the need for a paediatric dietitian referral for infants who are complementary feeding (weaning) and older children is based on the ESPGHAN guidelines and the MAP guideline.
Management following a trial elimination diet
  • The recommendations on when and how to arrange a home reintroduction are largely based on the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014], the EAACI guideline [Muraro, 2014], the updated iMAP guideline [Fox, 2019], and are supported by expert opinion in a review article [Venter, 2017].
    • Following an elimination diet, the child should be assessed for a clear improvement of symptoms, not necessarily complete resolution of symptoms [Venter, 2017].
    • The BSACI guideline states that a cow's milk elimination diet and home milk reintroduction remain the diagnostic gold standard for the assessment of non-IgE-mediated allergy. This uses the principle that symptoms improve or resolve with allergen exclusion and reappear with reintroduction of cow's milk.
    • The information that in exclusively breastfed infants, cow's milk should be reintroduced into the maternal diet in previously consumed amounts, over a one-week period is based on the MAP guideline.
    • The EAACI guideline notes that when a properly performed elimination diet does not improve symptoms, food allergy to the eliminated food is highly unlikely.
    • The MAP guideline recommends specialist allergy clinic referral if cow's milk allergy is still suspected, as the child may have multiple food allergies requiring more complex elimination regimens and assessment. 
Advising on sources of information and support
  • The recommendation to offer information and support is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014], the EAACI guidelines [Muraro, 2014], the World Allergy Organization publication [Fiocchi et al, 2010], the updated iMAP guideline [Fox, 2019], and expert opinion in review articles [Ludman et al, 2013; Venter et al, 2013; Martorell-Aragones, 2015; Venter, 2017].
    • The information that allergy testing with skin prick tests or serum-specific IgE antibody tests is not needed if there is suspected non-IgE-mediated allergy is based on the World Allergy Organization publication and expert opinion in the updated MAP guideline and in review articles [Ludman et al, 2013; Venter, 2017].
    • The BSACI guideline highlights the need to avoid cow's milk and milk products, and advise on dietary substitution with nutritionally suitable milk alternatives. It also notes that nutritionally incomplete substitutes can cause faltering growth and nutritional deficiencies.
    • The importance of education about interpreting food labelling, hidden sources of milk proteins, for example in loose and unwrapped foods, and the risks of inadvertent exposure are highlighted in the BSACI guideline, the EAACI guidelines, the World Allergy Organization publication, and expert opinion in review articles [Ludman et al, 2013; Venter et al, 2013].
    • The examples of different labels or names for cow's milk protein are extrapolated from expert opinion in a review article on IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy [Martorell-Aragones, 2015].
